description: System-generated unique identifier for the schedule record (surrogate key used for joins and internal references).
Business-facing schedule identifier used in the application or integrations; may differ from the internal primary key.
Short text describing the scheduled maintenance or service activity.
Code referencing the type/category of work order this schedule will create (e.g., PM, inspection); confirm lookup.
Current lifecycle state of the schedule (e.g., planned, active, closed), stored as a status code; confirm mapping.
Shift or time window when the work is scheduled (e.g., day, swing); likely references a shift master; confirm with SME.
Required technician trade/skill for the scheduled work (e.g., electrician, mechanic); likely references a skills list; confirm with SME.
Project or cost objective associated with the scheduled work; used for reporting and chargeback.
Supervisor or responsible person/team overseeing the scheduled work; likely references a user/role.
Defines how lockout/blackout rules are applied during scheduling (e.g., prevent during asset downtime or calendar blocks); confirm option codes with SME.
Flag indicating whether multiple maintenance procedures are combined into a single generated work order.
Flag indicating whether work for multiple assets is combined into a single generated work order.
Flag to bypass calendar lockout rules and allow scheduling during otherwise restricted periods.
Bitmask or coded flags controlling additional scheduling behavior/settings; values are system-specific; confirm mapping.
Default warehouse/site from which parts and materials will be issued for this scheduled work; references a warehouse ID.
Free-text notes about the schedule.
System timestamp of the most recent change to this schedule record.
User who created the assignment or designated the assignee for this schedule.
User, technician, crew, or vendor assigned to perform the scheduled work.
Priority level indicating urgency or scheduling precedence for the work (e.g., low to high); confirm code set.
Timestamp of the last modification performed by a user action rather than an automated process; confirm semantics.
Status code of the work order(s) generated from this schedule, if applicable; confirm mapping.
Indicator that the schedule was loaded via data import/integration rather than created manually (0/1 or similar).
Identifier of the user who created the schedule record.
Timestamp when the schedule record was created.
Identifier of the user who last modified the schedule record.
Timestamp when the schedule record was last modified by a user.
